learning_outcomes.description: Apply horticultural principles for sustainable production and postharvest practices, based on an understanding of physiological processes of plant growth and development.
Design and execute an experiment on a horticultural crop.
Analyse, interpret and report on the results, outcomes and applications of an experiment.
Prepare a scientific presentation and deliver information verbally to a general audience.
Find, evaluate and synthesise scientific information in relation to a horticultural topic of interest and express it in written form

assessments.task_description:
Students are to choose a topic of their own interest related to horticultural science and of general importance to the Australian and/or international horticultural industry. The topics may include challenges faced in horticulture today, with solutions that promote the sustainable production of fresh produce for the domestic or export market. After deciding on a topic (please consult Course Coordinator for suitability), use a UQ Library database, such as Web of Science or Science Direct to search for relevant scientific literature. Select a minimum of 5 related, peer reviewed, journal papers and synthesise the information (put the information together) to form an argument.

Your argument will be delivered as a Poster that will be presented to the audience. This will be 3 Minute Thesis (3MT) style. Make it punchy and impactful. Your job is to drive change.

You will be marked on the quality of your poster and presentation. Students will submit the poster on the due date (Monday, 23 March 2026) and present it to other students and examiners in class on the same day. This assessment item will be marked by two examiners.

Further details for this assessment, including the marking criteria, will be available in the course Blackboard site.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see the assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The assessment is completed within Blackboard under the appropriate assessment title on your course Blackboard site. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.weighting: <dd>30% Each sequential item contributes 10% towards the sequential practical reports (total 30%). </dd>
assessments.task_description:
All students will undertake their own home-based seed germination experiment as part of their assessment. Attendance at practicals will assist students with a key understanding of the experiment requirements.

Students will prepare 3 practical reports that build on experiments you will perform at home.

These will be:

  1. Experimental design and set up
  2. Monitoring of results
  3. Analysis of results and Full report


This is a continuous piece of assessment.

Further details for this assessment, including the marking criteria, will be available in the course Blackboard site.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, in Blackboard, via the Turnitin link by the submission deadline. You should also retain an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The exam may cover any content delivered in this course, including lectures, guest lectures, textbook chapters outlined in the Learning Activities, and practicals.

It will consist of short essay type answers (a few paragraphs per question).

The exam will be an on-campus exam. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.  

Students enrolled in In Person delivery must attend the exam in-person. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture series

A wide range of lectures covering different horticulture topics will be provided. For more details on the content for each week, please refer to the Blackboard site and the Week 1 course introduction lecture.


Learning outcomes: L01, L05

learning_activities.topic:
Laboratory Activities, Field Visits and Study Tours

The practical component of this course includes several laboratory activities, a field visit, and a study tour. In Weeks 1-3, the practical will be held in laboratory 8111-230. More details about the field visit and study tour will be provided on the Blackboard site and discussed during the Week 1 lecture.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
